entry.title: API Card
entry.summary: As of LockLogin 1.13.16, you can implement API cards. These cards contain information to communicate the plugin and your module. For example, you can create…
entry.content:
As of LockLogin 1.13.16, you can implement API cards. These cards contain information to communicate the plugin and your module.

For example, you can create (in your module) a card named 'logged', and in the plugin, consume that card and perform an action over the card container. I know you did not understand anything, so... let me explain to you what I am talking about

In your module

public class TeleportCard extends APICard<ModulePlayer> {
    
    private ModulePlayer player;

    /**
     * Initialize the teleport card
     *
     * @param module the module owning this card
     * @param client the client managed in this card
     */
    public TeleportCard(final PluginModule module, final ModulePlayer client) {
        super(module, "teleport");
        player = client;
    }

    /**
     * Update the card object
     *
     * @param update the update value
     */
    @Override
    protected final void update(final ModulePlayer update) {
        if (CurrentPlatform.getServer().isValid(update)) {
            player = update;
        }
    }

    /**
     * Get the card value
     *
     * @return the card value
     */
    @Override
    public final ModulePlayer get() {
        return player;
    }
}
public final class Listener implement EventListener {

    private final PluginModule module;

    public Listener(final PluginModule owner) {
        module = owner;
    }
 
    public void onAuth(UserAuthenticateEvent e) {
        ModulePlayer player = e.getPlayer();
        TeleportCard card = new TeleportCard(module, player);

        module.queueCard(card);
    }
}

In your plugin

public class Main extends JavaPlugin {
    
    @Override
    public void onEnable() {
        APICard.addCardListener(new CardAdapter() {
            /**
             * When a card has been completely queued
             *
             * @param event the card queue event wrapper
             */
            @Override
            public void cardPostQueued(CardPostQueueEvent event) {
                //The APICard owner module
                PluginModule module = event.getModule();
                //Where the APICard is stored, it's usually the same as 'getModule'
                PluginModule container = event.getContainer();

                //The APICard name identifier
                String identifier = event.getIdentifier();
                
                if (container.consumeCard(module, identifier)) {
                    //Make the module consume the card and remove it from the queue, so it can
                    //be loaded using the getCard method
                    
                    APICard<ModulePlayer> card = container.getCard(module, identifier);
                    
                    UUID id = card.get().getUUID();
                    Player player = getServer().getPlayer(id);
                    
                    player.teleport(/* somewhere */);
                }
            }
        });
    }
}

Please note in the previous example the plugin only listens when a card is queued completely. But the correct way to read cards is using PluginModule#consumeCard(String) method and then using the PluginModule#getCard(String) method. Consuming a card means that the card will be removed from the queue cards and put to a temporal field to be accessed using the get card method. Not doing that could cause errors and high memory usage.

A correct way of listening to plugin ABC cards would be this

while (true) {
    if (module.consumeCard("teleport")) {
        APICard<ModulePlayer> card = module.getCard("teleport");

        //Do whatever you want
    }
}

Or this:

String[] identifiers = new String[]{"teleport", "another_example"}

//Inside an async task
while (true) {
    for (String str : identifiers) {
        module.consumeCard(str);
    }
}
//Outside the async task

APICard.addCardListener(new CardAdapter() {
  /**
   * When a card has been completely queued
   *
   * @param event the card queue event wrapper
   */
  @Override
  public void cardPostQueued(CardConsumedEvent event) {
    //The APICard owner module
    PluginModule module = event.getModule();
    //Where the APICard is stored, it's usually the same as 'getModule'
    PluginModule container = event.getContainer();

    //The APICard name identifier
    String identifier = event.getIdentifier();

    APICard < ModulePlayer > card = container.getCard(module, identifier);

    UUID id = card.get().getUUID();
    Player player = getServer().getPlayer(id);

    player.teleport( /* somewhere */ );
  }
});

or you could even use the provided card event handler like this:

/**
 * When a card has been completely queued
 *
 * @param event the card queue event wrapper
 */
@Override
public void cardPostQueued(CardPostQueueEvent event) {
    PluginModule container = event.getContainer();
    container.consumeCard(identifier);
}

By default LockLogin provides you with theese APICards;

Card Type Description
ClientCard ModulePlayer This card can be used by any plugin and its module to act as a player and this action is always under the same conditions
MultiQueueCard Set as APICard This card can be used when you need to send more than one API card containing more than one type of data in a single queue. I recommend always creating a class wrapper specified for this, but if you don't want to, here's the option
QueueCard Any object this This card can be used always, it can contain any kind of object, including class wrappers of data

entry.title: Account manager
entry.summary: You can create your account manager or interact with the current one, using just the LockLogin API First, create a class that extends AccountManager, for…
entry.content:
You can create your account manager or interact with the current one, using just the LockLogin API

Creating own account manager

First, create a class that extends AccountManager, for correct work reasons, you must provide 3 constructors and should provide another one, which is optional but highly recommended

This is just an example, you don't need to make use of KarmaYamlManager or even use files, you could use JSON, MySQL, or anything meanwhile it extends AccountManager

public final class MyAccountManager extends AccountManager {

    //When creating a module you must use KarmaAPI
    private final KarmaYamlManager account;
    private final File file;

    //Required constructor
    public AccountManager() {
        account = null;
        file = null;
    }

    /*
    * Required constructor
    *
    * LockLoginAPI is compatible with bukkit/bungee/velocity API, you can use it
    * in your modules
    */
    public AccountManager({OfflinePlayer-ProxyPlayer-[Velocity]Player} player) {
        account = /*module object*/.loadFile(player.getUniqueId().toString().replace("-", ""), "accounts");
        file = (File) account.getSourceRoot().getSource();
    }

    //Required constructor
    public AccountManager(AccountID id) {
        account = /*module object*/.loadFile(id.getId().replace("-", ""), "accounts");
        file = (File) account.getSourceRoot().getSource();
    }

    //Recommended constructor
    public AccountManager(File file) {
        account = new KarmaYamlManager(file);
        this.file = file;
    }

    /**
     * Check if the file exists
     *
     * @return if the file exists
     */
    public boolean exists() {
        
    }

    /**
     * Tries to create the account
     *
     * @return if the account could be created
     */
    public boolean create() {
       
    }

    /**
     * Tries to remove the account
     *
     * @param issuer the account removal issuer
     * @return if the account could be removed
     */
    public boolean remove(final String issuer) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Save the account id
     *
     * @param id the account id
     */
    public void saveUUID(final AccountID id) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Save the account 2FA status
     *
     * @param status the account 2FA status
     */
    public void set2FA(final boolean status) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Import the values from the specified account manager
     *
     * @param account the account
     */
    protected void importFrom(final AccountManager account) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Get the account id
     *
     * @return the account id
     */
    public AccountID getUUID() {
        
    }

    /**
     * Get the account name
     *
     * @return the account name
     */
    public String getName() {
        
    }

    /**
     * Save the account name
     *
     * @param name the account name
     */
    public void setName(final String name) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Save the account password
     *
     * @param password the account password
     */
    public void setPassword(final String password) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Save the account password unsafely
     *
     * @param password the account password
     */
    public void setUnsafePassword(final String password) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Get the account password
     *
     * @return the account password
     */
    public String getPassword() {
        
    }

    /**
     * Get if the account is registered
     *
     * @return if the account is registered
     */
    public boolean isRegistered() {
        
    }

    /**
     * Save the account google auth token
     *
     * @param token the account google auth
     *              token
     */
    public void setGAuth(final String token) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Save the account unsafe google auth token
     *
     * @param token the account google auth token
     */
    public void setUnsafeGAuth(final String token) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Get the account google auth token
     *
     * @return the account google auth
     * token
     */
    public String getGAuth() {
        
    }

    /**
     * Save the account pin
     *
     * @param pin the account pin
     */
    public void setPin(final String pin) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Save the account unsafe pin
     *
     * @param pin the account pin
     */
    public void setUnsafePin(final String pin) {
        
    }

    /**
     * Get the account pin
     *
     * @return the account pin
     */
    public String getPin() {
        
    }

    /**
     * Get if the account has a pin
     *
     * @return if the account has a pin
     */
    public boolean hasPin() {
        
    }

    /**
     * Check if the account has 2FA
     *
     * @return if the account has 2FA
     */
    public boolean has2FA() {
        
    }

    /**
     * Get the account creation time
     *
     * @return the account created time
     */
    public Instant getCreationTime() {
        
    }

    /**
     * Get a list of accounts
     *
     * @return a list of all the
     * Available accounts
     */
    public Set<AccountManager> getAccounts() {
        Set<AccountManager> managers = new HashSet<>();

        Path accounts = /*module object*/.getDataPath().resolve("accounts");
        Files.list(accounts).forEach(file -> managers.add(new MyAccountManager(file.toFile())));

        return managers;
    }
}

After creating the account manager

You must register that account manager as the current account system provider

public class Main extends PluginModule {

    /**
     * On module enable logic
     */
    @Override
    public void enable() {
        CurrentPlatform.setAccountsManager(MyAccountManager.class);
    }

    /**
     * On module disable logic
     */
    @Override
    public void disable() {
        AccountManager default = CurrentPlatform.getDefaultAccountManager(new Class[0]);
        CurrentPlatform.setAccountsManager(default.getClass());
    }
}

Interacting with the current account manager

You can interact with the current account manager by retrieving it from a player, or using CurrentPlatform provided by LockLogin

By player

public AccountManager retrieve(final UUID id) {
    ModulePlayer player = CurrentPlatform.getServer().getPlayer(id);
    return player.getAccount();
}

public AccountManager retrieve(final String name) {
    ModulePlayer player = CurrentPlatform.getServer().getPlayer(name);
    return player.getAccount();
}

By CurrentPlatform

public AccountManager retrieve(final UUID id) {
    AccountManager manager = CurrentPlatform.getAccountManager(new Class[]{AccountID.class}, AccountId.fromUUID(id));
}

public AccountManager retrieve(final String name) {
    AccountManager invalid = CurrentPlatform.getAccountManager(new Class[0]);
    for (AccountManager manager : invalid.getAccounts()) {
        if (manager.getName().equalsIgnoreCase(name)) {
            return manager;
        }
    }
    
    return null;
}

entry.title: Module Player
entry.summary: LockLoginAPI doesn't have a "Player" object, but a ModulePlayer you can interact with. ModulePlayer is an object that allows you to retrieve player info from…
entry.content:
LockLoginAPI doesn't have a "Player" object, but a ModulePlayer you can interact with.

What is a ModulePlayer

ModulePlayer is an object that allows you to retrieve player info from a LockLogin module, without using bukkit/velocity/bungeecord API.

ModulePlayer allows you to:

  • Retrieve player name
  • Retrieve player UUID
  • Retrieve player LockLogin session
  • Retrieve player LockLogin account
  • Retrieve player IP address
  • Retrieve player bukkit/velocity/bungeecord player object
  • Retrieve a player object of bukkit/velocity/bungeecord API ( as object )
  • Retrieve if the player is playing in the server
  • Send a message to the player
  • Send an actionbar to the player
  • Send a title/subtitle to the player
  • Send a kick request for the player
  • Send a login request for the player
  • Send an unlogin request for the player

LockLogin session

By default, LockLogin provides a session manager ( which can be changed by any module ).

But what does that session do?

LockLogin session manages if the player:

  • Is logged
  • Is temp-logged
    • 2FA logged
    • Pin logged
  • Is captcha logged
  • Is Bungee/Velocity verified ( Bungee Hack protection )
  • Retrieve player captcha

Also, allows you to manage:

  • Player login status
  • Player temp-login status
    • 2FA login
    • Pin login
  • Player captcha login status
  • Bungee/Velocity verification status ( Bungee Hack protection )
public void onJoin(UserPostJoinEvent e) {
    ModulePlayer player = e.getPlayer();
    ClientSession session = player.getSession();

    session.setCaptchaLogged(true);
    player.sendActionBar("&aWelcome &7" + player.getName());
}

LockLogin account

LockLogin account allows you to manage the player account

  • Player stored name
  • Player stored UUID
  • Player password
  • Player 2FA token
  • Player pin
  • Player account creation date
  • Retrieve if player is registered
  • Retrieve if player has 2fa
  • Retrieve if player has pin
public void onJoin(UserPostJoinEvent e) {
    ModulePlayer player = e.getPlayer();
    ClientSession session = player.getSession();
    AccountManager account = player.getAccount();

    session.setCaptchaLogged(true);
    if (account.isRegistered()) {
        player.sendActionBar("&aWelcome &7" + player.getName());
    } else {
        player.sendActionBar("&bHi &7" + player.getName() + "&b. Welcome to MyServer!");
    }
}

entry.title: Commands API
entry.summary: LockLoginAPI commands allows you to create your own command managed by LockLogin. This command will be visible only by LockLogin. First of all, you should…
entry.content:
LockLoginAPI commands allows you to create your own command managed by LockLogin. This command will be visible only by LockLogin.

Getting started

First of all, you should create a class that extends Command object

public final class MyCommand extends Command {

    public MyCommand() {
        super("My command description", "label1", "alias1", "alias2" /*You can add an infinite number of alias*/);
    }

    /**
     * Process the command when
     * its fired
     *
     * @param arg        the used argument
     * @param sender     the command sender
     * @param parameters the command parameters
     */
    @Override
    public void processCommand(String arg, ModuleSender sender, String... parameters) {
        if (parameters.length == 0) {
            sender.sendMessage("&cPlease provide an argument");
        } else {
            sender.sendMessage("&bHello " + parameters[0]);
        }
    }
}

Registering the command

Obviously, the command won't work by just creating the command class, you must register in your ModulePlugin class

public class Main extends PluginModule {

    /**
     * On module enable logic
     */
    @Override
    public void enable() {
        getPlugin().registerCommand(new MyCommand());
    }

    /**
     * On module disable logic
     */
    @Override
    public void disable() {
        getPlugin().unregisterCommand(new MyCommand());
    }
}

entry.title: API Events
entry.summary: The plugin events are divided into 3 categories: Each category contains what its name says, plugins, and user-related events. Plugin events Event Description Methods MigrationRequestEvent…
entry.content:
The plugin events are divided into 3 categories:

Table of Contents

  • Plugin events
  • Server Events
  • Client Events

Each category contains what its name says, plugins, and user-related events.

Plugin events

Event Description Methods
MigrationRequestEvent This event is fired when the plugin
starts to migrate an account from an
AccountManager to another one		 #getSource
#getTarget
ModuleStatusChangeEvent This event is fired when a module changes
his status to loaded or unloaded		 #getStatus
#getModule
#getLoader
PluginIpValidationEvent This event is fired when the plugin validates the IP in these cases:
- The IP pinged server
- The IP is valid
- The IP is not from a known proxy		 #setHandled(PluginModule, ValidationResult, Boolean, String)
#getHandleOwner
#getProcess
#getResult
PluginProcessCommandEvent This event is fired when the plugin process
a module command		 #getArgument
#getParameters
#getSender
PluginStatusChangeEvent This event is fired when the plugin changes
his status to loaded, unloaded, reload_start,
reload_end or update_start, update_end		 #getStatus
UpdateRequestEvent This event is fired when the plugin requests
to update himself		 #getSender
#canPerformUnsafeUpdate ( deprecated )

Server Events

Event Description Methods
ModuleServerMessageEvent This event (inherits from ServerSendMessageEvent) is fired when a module sends a message to the console #setReplace(Integer, Object)
#addReplacement(Object)
#getModule
#getReplacesAmount
#getReplaces
#getReplace(Integer)
#setMessage(String)
#getMessage
ServerSendMessageEvent This event is not fired as it's currently fired from an abstract object, but this event is fired when a module sender sends a message to the console #setMessage(String)
#getMessage

Client Events

Event Description Methods
AccountCloseEvent This event is fired when an account is closed but the player stills in the game #getPlayer
#getIssuer
AccountCreatedEvent This event is fired when an account is created #getPlayer
AccountRemovedEvent This event is fired when an account is removed #getRemovedAccount
#getIssuer
SessionInitializationEvent This event is fired when the plugin initializes
a client session		 #getPlayer
#getSession
UserAuthenticateEvent This event is fired when a player tries authenticate
his credentials:
- Register
- Login
- Pin
- 2FA		 #getPlayer
#getAuthType
#getAuthResult
#getAuthMessage
UserHookEvent This event is fired when a player is hooked by the plugin.

This event is fired before his session is created, but is
recognized by LockLogin as an humman valid player		 #getPlayer
UserJoinEvent This event is fired when a player joins the server, before validating
he's secure and is valid for the server		 #getIp
#getAccountId
#getName
UserPostJoinEvent This event is fire when the player account has been completely initialized
and has been secure-verified by the plugin for the server and is secure to manipulate
him		 #getPlayer
UserPreJoinEvent This event is fired before the player joins the server, and before is even recognized as player
by the server		 #getIp
#getAccountId
#getName
UserQuitEvent This event is fired when a player leaves the server, independent of the reason, if a player
is not longer in the server, this event will be fired		 #getPlayer
UserUnHookEvent This event is fired when a player is unhooked from the plugin, but not necessarily because he
left the server		 #getPlayer
VelocityGameProfileEvent This event is fired only in Velocity, and its fired when Velocity requests the client game profile, containing UUID, Skin properties etc...

entry.title: Creating Events
entry.summary: Introduction The LockLogin API has some events to make it easier for you to listen for when something happens, anyway, you can create your event…
entry.content:
Introduction

The LockLogin API has some events to make it easier for you to listen for when something happens, anyway, you can create your event and offer it as API so more modules can use your events.
It's relatively funny how similar this is to the bukkit API right? I made it so it will be easier for developers to use my API. Let's start

Table of Contents

  • Introduction
    • Creating my first event
      • Step One
      • Step two
  • Registering an event listener
    • After creating the EventListener
  • Full Event List
  • Handling events
    • What is handling an event in LockLogin

Creating my first event

The only thing you will need is basic knowledge of java, nothing more.

Step One

Create a class with the name of the event, which extends eu.locklogin.api.module.plugin.api.event.util.Event

public final class ClientFastAuthEvent extends Event {
     
     private final Object eventObj;
     private boolean handled = false;
     
     /**
     * Initialize the event
     *
     * If your event is called from another
     * event, please make use of the "getEvent()"
     * method, so external APIs can use it to reflect
     * into the original event. Otherwise, parse eventOwner
     * as null.
     */
     public ClientFastAuthEvent(final Object eventOwner) {
         eventObj = eventOwner;
     }
     
     /**
     * Check if the event has been handled
     *
     * @return if the event has been handled
     */
     @Override
     public final boolean isHandled() {
         return handled;
     }

     /**
     * Set the event handle status
     *
     * @param status the handle status
     */
     @Override
     public final void setHandled(boolean status) {
         handled = status;
     }
     
     /**
     * Get the event instance
     *
     * @return the event instance
     */
    @Override
    public final @Nullable Object getEvent() {
        return eventObj;
    }
}

Step two

public final class ClientFastAuthEvent extends Event {
     
     private final Object eventObj;
     private final ModulePlayer client;
     private boolean handled = false;
     
     /**
     * Initialize the event
     *
     * If your event is called from another
     * event, please make use of the "getEvent()"
     * method, so external APIs can use it to reflect
     * into the original event. Otherwise, parse eventOwner
     * as null.
     */
     public ClientFastAuthEvent(final Object eventOwner, final ModulePlayer player) {
         eventObj = eventOwner;
         client = player;
         command = cmd;
     }
     
     public final ModulePlayer getPlayer() {
         return player;
     }

     /**
     * Check if the event has been handled
     *
     * @return if the event has been handled
     */
    @Override
    public final boolean isHandled() {
        return handled;
    }

    /**
     * Set the event handle status
     *
     * @param status the handle status
     */
    @Override
    public final void setHandled(boolean status) {
        handled = status;
    }
 
     /**
     * Get the event instance
     *
     * @return the event instance
     */
    @Override
    public final @Nullable Object getEvent() {
         return eventObj;
    }
}

Registering an event listener

You can also listen to other LockLogin events or module events by creating an EventListener

public class JoinListener implements EventListener {

    private final static Map<String, BPremiumUtils> utilMap = new HashMap<>();

    @ModuleEventHandler(priority = ModuleEventHandler.Priority.LAST)
    public void onJoin(UserPreJoinEvent e){
        ModulePlayer player = e.getPlayer();
        MyConfigurationObject configuration = new MyConfigurationObject();
        if (configuration.hasFastLogin(player.getUUID())) {
            ClientFastAuthEvent event = new ClientFastAuthEvent(e, player);
            ModulePlugin.callEvent(event);

            if (!event.isHandled()) {
               player.requestLogin();
            }
        }
    }
}

After creating the EventListener

public class Main extends PluginModule {

    /**
     * On module enable logic
     */
    @Override
    public void enable() {
        getPlugin().registerListener(new JoinListener());
    }

    /**
     * On module disable logic
     */
    @Override
    public void disable() {
        getPlugin().unregisterListener(new JoinListener());
    }
}

Full Event List

Click Me

Handling events

When using the API, you may have noticed there're 3 extra methods, in all the event objects, which are

Event.isHandleable() //Returns if the event can be handled
Event.isHandled() //Returns if the event is handled
Event.getHandleReason() // Returns the event handle reason
Event.setHandled(Boolean, String) // Set the event handle status and reason
Event.getEvent() // Get the event parent event, this can be another LockLogin event, bukkit event, bungee event, or even velocity event

What is handling an event in LockLogin

Handling an event in LockLogin means you have taken the event and you've done some action on it or some of its recipients.

For example, UserJoinEvent. By handling this event, the client would be kicked with the handle reason. Why? Handling an event is like stopping it to keep going, and stopping joining an event means stopping client connection requests.

But not all events can be handled, there's a list of which events can be handled.

Plugin events   Server events   Client events  
MigrationRequestEvent ❌ ModuleServerMessageEvent ✅ AccountCloseEvent ❌
ModuleStatusChangeEvent ❌ ServerSendMessageEvent ✅ AccountCreatedEvent ❌
PluginIpValidationEvent ✅   ❓ AccountRemovedEvent ❌
PluginProcessCommandEvent ✅   ❓ SessionInitializationEvent ❌
PluginStatusChangeEvent ❌   ❓ UserAuthenticateEvent ❌
UpdateRequestEvent ❌   ❓ UserHookEvent ❌
  ❓   ❓ UserJoinEvent ✅
  ❓   ❓ UserPostJoinEvent ✅
  ❓   ❓ UserPreJoinEvent ✅
  ❓   ❓ UserQuitEvent ❌
  ❓   ❓ UserUnHookEvent ❌
  ❓   ❓ VelocityGameProfileEvent ❌

entry.title: How To Create A Module
entry.summary: Creating your first module First, create a main class that extends PluginModule. package com.mymodule.bukkit; import eu.locklogin.api.common.injector.loader.JarInJarClassLoader; import eu.locklogin.api.common.injector.loader.LoaderBootstrap; import eu.locklogin.api.module.PluginModule; public class Main extends PluginModule…
entry.content:
Creating your first module

First, create a main class that extends PluginModule.

package com.mymodule.bukkit;

import eu.locklogin.api.common.injector.loader.JarInJarClassLoader;
import eu.locklogin.api.common.injector.loader.LoaderBootstrap;
import eu.locklogin.api.module.PluginModule;

public class Main extends PluginModule {

    /**
     * On module enable logic
     */
    @Override
    public void enable() {
        //Do something
    }

    /**
     * On module disable logic
     */
    @Override
    public void disable() {
        //Do something
    }
}

Module.yml

Before compiling and using the module, you will need to set up a module.yml so LockLogin can read it and use the module.yml information to load your module.

The module.yml looks like this:

name: ModuleName
version: ModuleVersion
description:
  - "This is the module"
  - "description, it can be a string"
  - "an array or even a list"
load: PREPLUGIN #You can also use POSTPLUGIN
author: ModuleAuthor
update_url: "https://mydomain.com/modulename/" #There must exist a latest.txt file
loader_bukkit: path.to.my.main.class.for.bukkit.extending.PluginModule
loader_bungee: path.to.my.main.class.for.bungee.extending.PluginModule
loader_velocity: path.to.my.main.class.for.velocity.extending.PluginModule

latest.txt format

1.0.0
https://mydomain.com/modulename/Latest.jar

LockLogin API has more features, but it will be better for you to check javadocs

entry.title: API - Getting Started
entry.summary: Interdiction The LockLogin API is simple and robust. Allows you to create modules and compatibility with other plugins Before knowing how to start with a…
entry.content:
Interdiction

The LockLogin API is simple and robust.
Allows you to create modules and compatibility with other plugins

Before knowing how to start with a LockLogin module, you must know how the API work. As in the other plugins, there's a method, you call it and it does things, the difference between LockLogin and these plugin's APIs, is that LockLogin doesn't want a plugin to use its API, why? security.

So the only way to interact with LockLogin is by creating a module, otherwise, you won't be able to interact with it.

How to import API

As almost all the plugins in spigotmc, LockLogin has an API, a little bit hard to start with, but it will be familiar for you as it is very similar to bukkit/bungee API.

To start, add the dependency to your pom.xml or Gradle, the dependency is hosted at the maven repo, most of the IDEs already search in that repository by default, so you don't have to add it to your repositories

API

COMMONS

Maven

<dependencies>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>eu.locklogin</groupId>
        <artifactId>LockLogin-API</artifactId>
        <version>{api-version}</version>
        <scope>provided</scope>
    </dependency>
    <!-- OPTIONAL -->
    <dependency>
        <groupId>eu.locklogin</groupId>
        <artifactId>LockLogin-common</artifactId>
        <version>{common-version}</version>
        <scope>provided</scope>
    </dependency>
</dependencies>

Gradle

dependencies {
    compile "eu.locklogin:LockLogin-API:{api-version}"
    
    //OPTIONAL
    compile "eu.locklogin:LockLogin-common:{common-version}"
}

entry.title: PlaceholderAPI
entry.summary: Since the version after legacy LockLogin ( 1.1.0.9 ), LockLogin has PlaceholderAPI support. Prefix Variable Description Complete locklogin logged Returns the amount of logged players…
entry.content:
Since the version after legacy LockLogin ( 1.1.0.9 ),
LockLogin has PlaceholderAPI support.

Prefix Variable Description Complete
locklogin logged Returns the amount of logged players %locklogin_logged%
locklogin registered Returns the amount of registered players %locklogin_registered%
locklogin islogged Returns if the player is completely logged %locklogin_islogged%
locklogin isregistered Returns if the player is registered %locklogin_isregistered%
locklogin creation Returns the creation date of the player account %locklogin_creation%
locklogin age Returns the player account age since he registered %locklogin_age%
